awd_titl_txt: CSR:  Small:  A Scalable and Efficient Framework for Switch Virtualization
awd_abstract_narration:
This project addresses network virtualization by developing a suite of bandwidth allocation and packet scheduling techniques as an integrated framework for switch virtualization. The goal is to achieve scalable, efficient, and isolated link sharing among virtual networks. 

Network virtualization allows for the creation of multiple coexisting logical networks, each customized to a specific purpose, by reorganizing the resources of a common physical infrastructure. Network virtualization has many important applications in delivering reduced hardware cost, improved resource utilization, simplified maintenance, and incremental service deployment. Implementation of network virtualization relies on creating slices for various resources of the underlying physical infrastructure. However, effective solutions are needed to create slices for switches, the important interconnecting components of any network. This project  develops  Scalability and Efficiency Aware Link Sharing (SEALS) framework for switch virtualization. 

This project  considers two types of switch virtualization: intra-switch virtualization which creates multiple logical switches within a physical one, and inter-switch virtualization which creates a logical switch by combining multiple heterogeneous physical ones. The SEALS framework accurately emulates the ideal Generalized Processor Sharing (GPS) model to realize scalable, efficient, and isolated switch virtualization. 

A combination of theoretical analysis, simulations, and experiments are used to evaluate the design. The SEALS framework is implemented in OpenFlow switches to obtain experimental data from a realistic environment. The outcome of this project will facilitate the creation of commercial and academic virtual networks to build cost-saving infrastructure or experiment new network prototypes. 

The educational component of this project offers research opportunities in computing to underrepresented minority groups, through summer workshops, curriculum development, and undergraduate research programs. Florida International University is among the top grantors of computer science and engineering degrees to Hispanic students in the nation. Its history of involving underrepresented groups in research efforts will be leveraged during the course of this project. The project web site will be used for dissemination of all publications, course materials, and source code resulted from the project.

por.por_cntn:
Network virtualization creates multiple coexisting logical virtual networks by reorganizing the resources of a common physical infrastructure. It brings many benefits such as reduced hardware and operation cost, accelerated time-to-market, and improved security. Existing approaches to share switch bandwidth among virtual networks suffer from several drawbacks, including impractical bandwidth allocation, weak traffic isolation, and poor performance guarantees. The research outcomes of this project include a suite of bandwidth allocation and switch scheduling techniques to achieve efficient, scalable, and performance-guaranteed bandwidth sharing among virtual networks, and the applications of the proposed techniques in various domains.
To ensure efficient and fair bandwidth sharing among virtual networks, the proposed switch virtualization solution has taken a two-step approach: first calculating the amount of allocated bandwidth for each virtual network, and then accurately emulating the ideal resource sharing model to ensure the allocated bandwidth. In detail, the bandwidth allocation algorithm adopts the max-min fairness principle, and calculates fair bandwidth allocation based on the demands of different virtual networks, from a global point of view considering constraints at both the inputs and outputs. We have theoretically proved that the algorithm not only achieves fair bandwidth allocation, but also fully utilizes all available bandwidth. Next, the switch scheduling algorithm reduces the switch scheduling problem to multiple instances of fair queuing problems, each utilizing a well-studied fair queuing algorithm. We have also shown by analysis that the algorithm can closely emulates the ideal resource sharing model to accurately guarantee the allocation bandwidth and create strong traffic isolation. Finally, as a comprehensive solution, we have also solved related challenges including allocating bandwidth for multicast flows, scheduling packets without segmentation-and-reassembly, and achieving performance guarantees for parallel switches.
To demonstrate the practicality of our design, we have applied the proposed switch virtualization techniques to various applications in different domains. To start with, leveraging the strong traffic isolation capability, we proposed multipath routing algorithms to fully utilize the available bisection bandwidth of the multi-rooted datacenter topologies. In addition, relying on separation of logical and physical devices via virtualization, we have shown how to maximize energy efficiency for data centers by consolidating switches and servers. Finally, combining with server virtualization, we have studied the optimal deployment of network services as virtual machines to efficiently implement network function virtualization.
The education outcomes of this project include contributions to a diversified STEM research community by involving underrepresented groups. Two female Ph.D. students, one African-American undergraduate student, and three Hispanic undergraduate students had been supported by the project, each of which coauthored one or more publications resulted from the project. In addition, the research results have been integrated as advanced topics and lab projects into multiple graduate and undergraduate courses at FIU.
